raw_text: Co-Training has been used before in applications like word-sense disambiguation (Yarowsky, 1995), web-page classification (Blum and Mitchell, 1998) and named entity identification (Collins and Singer, 1999)
clean_text: Co-Training has been used before in applications like word-sense disambiguation (Yarowsky, 1995), web-page classification (Blum and Mitchell, 1998) and named entity identification (Collins and Singer, 1999)

raw_text: They also discuss an application of classifying web pages by using their method of mutually constrained models. (Collins and Singer, 1999) further extend the use of classifiers that have mutual constraints by adding terms toAdaBoost which force the classifiers to agree (called Co Boosting)
clean_text: (Collins and Singer, 1999) further extend the use of classifiers that have mutual constraints by adding terms to AdaBoost which force the classifiers to agree (called Co Boosting)

raw_text: Recent methods for English NER focus on machine-learning algorithms such as DL-CoTrain, CoBoost [Collins and Singer 1999], HMM [Daniel M. Bikel 1997], maximum entropy model [Borthwick, et al 1999] and so on
clean_text: Recent methods for English NER focus on machine-learning algorithms such as DL-CoTrain, CoBoost [Collins and Singer 1999], HMM [Daniel M. Bikel 1997], maximum entropy model [Borthwick, et al 1999] and so on

raw_text: DL-CoTrain, (Collins and Singer, 1999), learns capitalized proper name NEs from a syn tactically analyzed corpus
clean_text: DL-CoTrain, (Collins and Singer, 1999), learns capitalized proper name NEs from a syntactically analyzed corpus

raw_text: (Collins and Singer, 1999) also makes use of competing categories (person, organization, and location), which cover 96% of all the instances itset out to classify
clean_text: (Collins and Singer, 1999) also makes use of competing categories (person, organization, and location), which cover 96% of all the instances it set out to classify

raw_text: In (Collins and Singer, 1999) Collins and Singer show that unlabeled data can be used to reduce the level of supervision required for named entity classification
clean_text: In (Collins and Singer, 1999) Collins and Singer show that unlabeled data can be used to reduce the level of supervision required for named entity classification

raw_text: Collins and Singer (1999) and Cucerzan and Yarowsky (1999) apply bootstrapping to the related task of named-entity recognition
clean_text: Collins and Singer (1999) and Cucerzan and Yarowsky (1999) apply bootstrapping to the related task of named-entity recognition

raw_text: Collins and Singer (1999) for example report that 88% of the named entities occurring in their data set belong to these three categories (Collins and Singer, 1999)
clean_text: Collins and Singer (1999) for example report that 88% of the named entities occurring in their data set belong to these three categories (Collins and Singer, 1999)

raw_text: While EM has worked quite well for a few tasks, notably ma chine translations (starting with the IBM models 1-5 (Brown et al, 1993), it has not had success inmost others, such as part-of-speech tagging (Merialdo, 1991), named-entity recognition (Collinsand Singer, 1999) and context-free-grammar induction (numerous attempts, too many to mention)
clean_text: While EM has worked quite well for a few tasks, notably machine translations (starting with the IBM models 1-5 (Brown et al, 1993), it has not had success in most others, such as part-of-speech tagging (Merialdo, 1991), named-entity recognition (Collinsand Singer, 1999) and context-free-grammar induction (numerous attempts, too many to mention)

raw_text: This can be either a fixed number of added unlabelled examples (Blum and Mitchell, 1998), the performance drop on a control set of labelled instances, or a filter on the disagreement of h1 and h2 in classifying U (Collins and Singer, 1999)

raw_text: In addition, we would also like to explore the semi-supervised techniques such as co-training and self-training (Collins and Singer, 1999)
